description: From Middle English servaunt, from Old French servant, from the present participle of the verb servir. Doublet of sergeant and servient. Morphologically serve +‎ -ant. Displaced native Old English þeġn.

entries.meaning: One who is hired to perform regular household or other duties, and receives compensation. As opposed to a slave.
examples: There are three servants in the household, the butler and two maids.

entries.meaning: One who serves another, providing help in some manner.
examples: She is quite the humble servant, the poor in this city owe much to her but she expects nothing.

entries.meaning: (religion) A person who dedicates themselves to God.
A person of low condition or spirit.

verbs.description: servant (third-person singular simple present servants, present participle servanting, simple past and past participle servanted)
